titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: I showed my proof of "Lourdes" to Dr Gillies, and he read it through. He expressed great approval, & some surprise at my scientific temper. "You would have made a first–rate man of science". He added that he had never suspected that the Papist doctrine about St Mary was so recent. Probably his opinion must be discounted by his civility. N.B. Mine host told me that Gillies is a New Zealander, who came up to Cambridge as a rather feeble youth. There he developed great athletic capacity: he rowed in the University Eight, played Cricket for the University & did other enviable things of that kind. In due course he became a distinguished surgeon, being particularly skilful in the remaking of countenances wrecked by the War.

Steel–Maitland motored us to Cloan. On the way we stopped to see Dunblane Cathedral, which has been well–restored. Lord Haldane, half–crippled with sciatica, received us with kindness: & after tea Miss Haldane walked us to a view–point on the adjacent hill, from which a noble prospect of mountains was gained.

Ralph arrived at dinner–time fresh from the Conference of Modern Churchmen at Oxford. He thought Fawkes's paper was too provocative, and had been assured by those who heard it that Barnes's pronouncement was dignified, persuasive, and powerful. The extracts printed in the newspapers had [217] not given me this impression. Ralph himself entered the lists in defence of Barnes, and his pronouncement will shortly appear in print. So the impudent address of the E.C.U. will have been answered: but of course, it will have done its work none the less, for those who read & enjoyed it will give no attention to the rejoinders. The ill consequences of religious controversies – viz: the embittering of resentments, deepening of prejudices, & hardening of partisan positions – are mainly connected with the fact that for the great majority of controversialists the process is not really controversial, but only a concentration of mind on a single point of view, & the confirmation of opinions by ceaseless iteration!

Lord Haldane is as incorrigibly optimistic as ever: he approves the subsidy: acquiesces in the apparent importance of the State in front of the Trade Unions: thinks that there is no real danger in the Communist movement: & assumes that we are passing comfortably into a new phase of social organization in which 'sovereignty will be divided'. But he doesn't really face the formidable practical issues which must be faced, & faced quickly, if the nation is to escape the most terrible disasters. If, as seems certain, the mining industry can only proceed on a much reduced scale, something like half a million men & lads will be permanently unemployed: how are they to be disposed of? That is the real problem first to be solved.
